results.title: Let's visit Alice Springs
results.creator_credit: Lex Halliday, Jean Halliday and Australian Instructional Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 23 of Series “Modern social studies”.
Alice Springs and the people who live there, shops and amenities, electric power plant, artesian water supply, public services, airport, schools, hospital and flying doctor service. Includes visits to the Hermannsberg Mission, the Royal Flying Doctor Servie. Flynn’s Memorial Church and the School of the Air.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lex Halliday, Jean Halliday and Australian Instructional Films

results.title: Sydney today
results.creator_credit: Lex Halliday, Jean Halliday and Australian Instructional Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Modern social studies”
Adapted from film of the same title originally produced for Textile Cones and Tubes Ltd. A travelogue of Sydney ranging from city streets to surfing beaches, centres of learning to expanding industries and homes to harbour activities.

results.title: Let's visit a cattle station
results.creator_credit: Lex Halliday, Jean Halliday and Australian Instructional Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 20 of Series “Modern social studies”.
An instructional film for classroom use. Tells of life on a Northern Territory cattle station. Isolation is the governing factor in the life of this and all other outback families - their daily routine involves tasks that must be done to ensure the functioning of the station as a self sufficient community. The children play their part by helping with mustering and branding - when they are not doing lessons by correspondence or school broadcasts.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lex Halliday, Jean Halliday and Australian Instructional Films
results.description:

The children play their part by helping with mustering and branding - when they are not doing lessons by correspondence or school broadcasts.

results.title: Australian aborigines: police tracker
results.brief_description:
Episode number 15 of Series “Modern social studies”.
Explains how Jackie the full blooded aboriginal police tracker from Katherine learnt this skill, which enables the aboriginal to hunt and the police to keep law and order and to save lives in Australia’s outback. Taken during the University of Sydney’s 1952 expedition to Arnhem Land and produced in collaboration with Professor A.P. Elkin, Professor of Anthropology, University of Sydney.

results.title: Australian Aborigines: everything from nature (A)
results.creator_credit: A.P. Elkin and Australian Instructional Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Modern social studies”.
Our reliance on manufactured goods is contrasted with the aborigines’ ability to use natural materials around them, which gives rise to a marked respect for their adaptability and sensitivity to the environment. Taked during an expedition by Sydney University to Arnhem Land in 1952.

results.creator_credit: A.P. Elkin and A I F
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Modern social studies”.
Taken during the University of Sydney’s 1952 expedition to Arnhem Land. This film shows how aborigines live on native animals and plants.

results.title: Australian Aborigines: art, life and religion
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Modern social studies”.
A simple portrayal of the aborigines’ belief that the spirit world and the material world are very closely linked. The spiritual significance of painting their bodies, dancing and singing is explained. Taken during the University of Sydney’s expedition to Arnhem Land, led by Professor A. P. Elkin in 1952.

Episode number 8 of Series “Modern social studies”.

results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Modern social studies”.
Taken during the Sydney University’s 1952 expedition to Arnhem Land. This film shows the musical instruments of the Aborigines and contrasts the songs and dances of different tribes. The story behind every song and dance is told by the commentator.
